item.title: 1.2 Examples
item.description:
Instantaneous Rate of Change given an Equation

Example 1: Quadratic Function

Let’s find the instantaneous rate of change of the function \( f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 1 \) at \( x = 3 \) using the first principles definition.

  1. Definition of the instantaneous rate of change:
\[ \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} \]
  1. Plug in the function and point:
\[ \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{(3+h)^2 - 2(3+h) + 1 - (3^2 - 2(3) + 1)}{h} \]
  1. Simplify the expression:
\[ = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{(9 + 6h + h^2 - 6 - 2h + 1) - (9 - 6 + 1)}{h} \]\[ = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{9 + 6h + h^2 - 6 - 2h + 1 - 9 + 6 - 1}{h} \]\[ = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{6h + h^2 - 2h}{h} \]\[ = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{4h + h^2}{h} \]\[ = \lim_{{h \to 0}} 4 + h \]
  1. Take the limit as \( h \) approaches 0:
\[ = 4 \]

So, the instantaneous rate of change of the function \( f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 1 \) at \( x = 3 \) is 4.

item.title: 1.2 Practice
item.description:
MCV4U 1.2 Instantaneous Rates of Change

Ex 1

Consider the quadratic function \( f(x) = x^2 + 2x + 1 \).

Question: Find the instantaneous rate of change of \( f(x) \) at \( x = 2 \).

Solution
  1. We can always use the First Princles Definition to find an IROC
\[ \text{Instantaneous Rate of Change} = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{f(a + h) - f(a)}{h} \]
  1. Calculate \( f(2 + h) \) and \( f(2) \):
\[ f(2 + h) = (2 + h)^2 + 2(2 + h) + 1 = 4 + 4h + h^2 + 4 + 2h + 1 = h^2 + 6h + 9 \]\[ f(2) = 2^2 + 2(2) + 1 = 4 + 4 + 1 = 9 \]
  1. Substitute into the formula and simplify:
\[ \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{(h^2 + 6h + 9) - 9}{h} = \lim_{{h \to 0}} \frac{h^2 + 6h}{h} = \lim_{{h \to 0}} (h + 6) \]
  1. Plug in zero for \( h \):
\[ \lim_{{h \to 0}} (h + 6) = 6 \]

If we directly plug in zero for \( h \), we get an indeterminate form \( \frac{0}{0} \). To find the true value, we generally need to apply algebraic techniques to these limits.
